description: The purpose of this course is to introduce students to a range of texts from the fields of literary theory and cultural studies. Besides offering them some methodological co-ordinates for their own future research and training them in techniques of discussing and writing clearly about complex ideas, the course is designed to stimulate students’ critical thinking. In particular, it is hoped that they will learn to reflect sceptically on the dominant cultural values of their own society and educational culture as a result of their close reading of essays and other works that bring into focus some of the most egregious products of stupefaction issuing from the west.

**Objectives**

This course orients students into various modes of contemporary theory including Western Marxism, psychoanalysis, postmodernism and research areas like biopolitics, and the posthuman. Students will learn to read, analyze, and critique all the required theoretical texts, which address such a variety of topics as modernity, technological reproduction, ideology, culture industry, drive, power, simulation, the (post)human and so on. They also learn to identify their research interests and build up their critical stances and frameworks.

**Requirements and grading policy**

Attendance 10%; discussions, short responses and commentaries (at least 3) 30%; group project and report 20%, term paper (around 10 pages) 40%
